intro: Phyllodoce tsugifolia var. oblongo-ovata, commonly known as the oblong-ovate mountain heath, is a shrub native to the Pacific Northwest of North America. It is characterized by its dense, low-growing habit and evergreen foliage, with leaves that are elliptic to oblong-ovate in shape. The plant typically grows in moist, shaded environments such as coniferous forests and rocky slopes. Its flowers are small, white, and clustered in dense inflorescences, often appearing in late spring to early summer. This variety is closely related to other members of the Ericaceae family, sharing similar ecological and morphological traits.
